for stealing two 5l. Bank of England notes, the property of
Amos William Coombe.
MESSRS. POLAND and MONTAGU WILLIAMS Prosecuted; MESSES. BESLEY and

ATHERLEY JONES
for Cherry; MR. LILLEY for Davis.

p.hi: The bank notes were in an envelope and were dropped by a servant of the
prosecutor on the premises. They were picked up by the prisoners Churchward and Jenkins, and were changed by the other prisoners. After hearing the evidence the
was of opinion that no case felony was established; he therefore permitted Churchward and Jenkins to withdraw their plea of

div1.p:
955.
JOSEPH HUSTON (38)
, Forging and uttering a warrant for the payment of 12l. 10s., with intent to defraud.

MONTAGUE HARRIS . I am a jeweller of York Lodge, Kennington Park—Mr. Theobald introduced the prisoner to me in May last year—the prisoner said he had some coupons which he wished to have discounted which belonged to the South London Tramways Company, and the interest was due on 1st January, 1884—these are the coupons (produced)—I paid "I can advance the money, but it is a most unusual thing for persons to detach coupons before the money is due"—he, said "They belong to my aunt, she gave them to me to get cashed to provide for my wife and family"—I asked for one to take to the Company's office to ask them whether they were genuine—I cannot identify the one I took, but I saw them all together—I made inquiries—I afterwards drew this cheque (produced) for 17l. 10s.; it has been paid—I gave it to Mr. Theobald; the prisoner was aware of that became he did not part with the coupons till I gave it to him.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I do not keep a shop—I know the Punch Tavern—I do not go there to business, I dine there—the cheque was made payable to Theobald—I held a promissory note for 1l. 5s.—I did not lend the money upon that, I took that as collateral security—I have known Theobald as a clerk—you are the first client he has introduced to me—you waited about outside the house, I paw you—I paid the coupons into my bank on 1st January, when they became due—I could not find you—I knew they were not right about seven days afterwards—I did not threaten to give Theobald into custody—I did not meet him at a tavern in Fleet Street the morning he was given in custody—I said to Theobald "You can give him into custody if you like"—I was reluctant to sign the charge sheet because I do not like the trouble of these things—I do not know if you received the money except from what Theobald told me—I saw you give the bonds to Theobald, and then you showed me a duplicate and said "They are right, or else a pawnbroker would not lend money upon them"—I sent you a letter, but found you had removed—the terms of the letter were that the bonds were forgeries, and asking you to pay the money—it might have been to the effect that the promissory note for 1l. 5s. was due—it stated "the coupons, my collateral security, are proved to be forgery."

CHARLES ALBERT THEOBALD . My office is at 12, New Street, Covent Garden—early in May the prisoner asked me if I knew any gentleman who lent money—I asked him upon what, and he produced seven coupons of the South London Tramways Company, one for 12l. 10s., one for 2l. 10s., and five for 1l. 5s. each—I asked him for his name and address, which he gave me—I asked him to leave one—he left one of the 1l. 5s. ones, and I was to let him know the result of my inquiry—I made inquiry—a few days afterwards I took him to Mr. Harris's house, 1, Camber
well New Road—on the second occasion I saw the prisoner I asked him

how he became possessed of them, and he said his aunt was a bondholder in the Company and had given him tile coupons for the purpose of raising money for his wife and family—he said "You see they are good business, because, a pawnbroker has lent on them," and he produced a ticket for one of these Coupons—I showed that to Harris—Harris ask ad him how he became possessed of them—he admitted that his aunt was a bondholder in the Company—Harris said he Would make inquiries let him knew through me whether the matter would be entertained—I took Harris to his stockbrokers—we also went to the Company's office, then I made an appointment with the prisoner to go to Harris's house—Harris drew this scheque (produced)—it Was a Bank Holiday, and the prisoner came to my house, which is only a stone's throw from Mr. Harris's house—I went across to Harris and gate him the coupons and the promissory note signed by the prisoner in exchange for the cheque—I went back to my house where the prisoner was waiting and said "Here is the cheque for 17l. 10s."—he said "It is Bank Holiday, what at we to do? I must have the money to-day"—I went to Harris, who directed me to a house in Westminster Bridge Road, where we got the cheque cashed by three 5l. notes in the and 2l. 10s. in gold—I gave the prisoner the 5l. notes drawing-room of my house and kept the 2l. 10s.—Harris said he should like a promissory note by way of collateral security, and I drew out the of produced, which the prisoner signed in my presencence—the latter part of April I received a communication in respect of these coupon not being paid—I gave the prisoner in charge to Constable Pepper at the Dolphin public-house, Ludgate Circus.

Cross-examined. I did not know you intimately before May—I am not a frequent visitor at the Dolphin—I never met any otie there—I do not do business in public-houses—I reside at 105, Hinton Street, Brunswick Square—I am a solicitor's clerk—I receive a salary now—I do not use my employer's name, nor go to public-courts, unless I am sent in the course of my business—my employer took me back after an imprisonment I had—I was charged with conspiracy, and the change was dismissed by the Magistrate—I never gave a bond—you signed a receipt for the purchase money, but I cannot find it.
Re-examined. Hunston was not with me when I took the coupon to the Company's office, Harris was—I was sot requested to leave the coupons.

WILLIAM ROBINSON . I am accountant Ealing—I was employed by the South London Tramways Company in April, last year—the coupons produced are not genuine—there are no private marks on them—I believe these were duplicates of some returned from the Bank having been paid—the numbers ate filled in irregularly in ink—the prisoner was temporarily employed by the Company about two years ago as a clerk—he would have access to the documents and papers.

Cross-examined. All genuine coupons have the private marks—those marks were put on 15 or 18 months ago—some bonds were sent out with the numbers in pen and ink—I do not remember that it was found that I had sent out some of the same numbers in type as had been sent out in ink.

HENRY CAMERON RICHARDSON . I am secretary of the South London Tramways Company—of these coupons produced the first lot are forgeries, those at the bottom are the Company's coupons issued from the office—

I know the first are not genuine because they have not our private mark upon them—that mark was put on in August or September, 1883—some false coupons were presented, and we wrote to every one of the bond
holders and had the private mark put on, and instructions were given to the bankers not to honour any without the mark—the mark was put on all the bonds, the last two we received back within a week—I was in doubt at the police-court about two bonds, but they have since come in for transfer and I see they have the mark on them—looking at the register I am able to say that these bonds were never attached to the debentures issued by the Company, also from the fact that we have the proper numbers paid and returned through the Bank, and the fact that these have not the Company's stamp upon them—the bonds and signatures are lithographed—the genuine bonds attached to the debentures have the private mark upon them.

Cross-examined. Some of the bonds were numbered with pen and ink—I do not know that any were put aside and not used—I ordered them to be destroyed—ink was used to complete a set of one denomination instead of sending to the printers, and in the case of a clerk spoiling a bond—I do not remember that some were made out in blank in error with the intention of being issued—that might have occurred in two or three cases—a figure "3" looks like mine, the other figures I am almost certain are not mine, but I should not like to swear to figures, even my own—the numbers being made with pen and ink would not prove forgery—not more than 5 per cent, were filled in with pen and ink—you filled up some bonds—duplicates of the bonds cannot be genuine.

Re-examined. When the bonds were called in the prisoner was not in the Company's employ—he was employed from January 28th to March 14th, and from July 18th to September 26th, 1882, so that the bonds were called in and private marks put on their backs about eleven months after he left.

GEORGE PEPPER (City Policeman 407). On 26th June Theobalds gave the prisoner in custody at Ludgate Circus—the prisoner made no state
ment—I found nothing on him relating to the charge.
Cross-examined. We passed Harris's house on the way to Brixton Station, and you said "Why does not Theobald go to Harris's house and bring him on at the same time?"—Theobald said he would not.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence said thot he did not know the bonds were forged, he had none of the money, and no doubt the bonds were put aside and got circulate amongst the public

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

956.
JOSEPH HUSTON was again indicted
for forging and uttering a warrant for 2l. 10s. also five warrants for 1l. 5s. each, with intent to defraud, upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

957.
HENRY CLIFFORD (35)
PLEADED GUILTY to feloniously mar
rying
Elizabeth Ann Hutton during the life of his wife.—
Three Day's Imprisonment.

958.
CHARLES HENRY HOARE (35)
to feloniously marrying
Emma Rosa Currie during the life of his wife.—
Three Days' Imprisonment
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

959.
EDWARD GEORGE HARRIS (34)
to unlawfully obtaining divers sums by false pretences. (MR. FRITH stated that he was the tool of
Walter Harmer, who had absconded, and would assist in his con
viction.)—
To enter into recognisances to appear for judgment when called upon.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.] And

960.
WILLIAM WOOD (34)
to two indictments for breaking and entering the dwelling-houses of
Amelia Brown and another, and stealing eleven medals and a breast-pin, their property, having been convicted of felony at this Court in November, 1878.—
To complete his previous term of imprisonment, and
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

961.
JOHN STEWART (19)
, Unlawfully assaulting
Antonio Franco, with intent, &c.
Second Count, indecent assault.

962.
GEORGE FISHER (42)
, Feloniously cutting and wounding
Susannah Fisher, with intent to do her grievous bodily harm.

SUSAINAH FISHER . I live at 56, Belvedere Road, Lambeth—I married the prisoner on 10th January—I carry on a general business—he was a stonemason—we have both queer tempers, and in August last I applied for a summons—I attended before the Magistrate, and the prisoner was discharged upon his giving some undertaking—he went away on the Friday and came back the following Wednesday evening, about 6 o'clock—he came to the room where I was lying—he asked me how I was, and if I had been on the sick list; he met with a cool reception—he was in and oat during the evening till 10 o'clock—I did not speak to him—the lodgers were upstairs—my mother came at 6 p.m., and my sister at 11.45—I sent for them—we were all together in the back parlour—at 12.30 the prisoner came in and knocked at the door and asked if we were in bed—my sister said I was in bed but she was not—he said "Is that you, Nellie?"—she said "Yes"—he went upstairs in the back bedroom, came down, and went into the back kitchen, where his tools are kept—he knocked at the door, my sister said "You can't come in, we are going; to bed"—then the door was burst in—the prisoner struck my sister a blow with a mallet, and she fell down—then he gave my mother a touch and she went down too—my mother put her hand across my sister's head, and he gave her a blow, and she fell, and my sister too—I was frightened, and got up to make way to the door; he gave me a blow—I do not feel the effects of it much, just a scar; it has got all right—I remained standing in the middle of the room, opposite the fireplace; I got up very soon after he struck me—I had two side blows from the mallet, they were very slight—the police came, and he was taken away.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. My Sister did not say you had no right in the house, and tell you to go where you had been—I had been ill—I do not know what the prisoner did say.

MARGARET LEE . I am 82 years of age—I am the mother of the last witness—she married the prisoner—I was with her and my other daughter on 13th August, in her back parlour—my other daughter came to take me home—the prisoner came in about 12.30—Susannah was going to bed—heard him go to the kitchen—he came back and burst the door in and gave Ellen two blows with a mallet, one on the ear, and I spread upon her to save her, and he gave me a blow and broke my arm—"I was taken to the hospital.
ELLEN MARY LEE . I was with my mother at Susannah Fisher's house when the prisoner came home—I declined to let him in—I heard him go

to the'kitchen and come back to the door—the door was burst in—I then received a blow on the side of my head which knocked me down in
Sensible—I was at the hospital eight days—I am suffering from deafness shortness of sight, and loss of memory.

Cross-examined. I went to Susannah's because I was sent for; I refused at first to go—I never threatened you, nor cut my finger with a knife—I never said I would run a knife into you—I hurt my wrist with a bracelet.

WILLIAM JOHN HARNETT . I am a lodger in this house—Some time after 12 o'clock on 14th August I went downstairs—I Saw the prisoner at the street-door—he had something in his hand—he threw it on the floor, it sounded heavy—afterwards, as I caught hold of him, he said "Let me go, I won't run away; I done it, and I intended to do it"—I took hold of him because he was making out at the door after my wife—I had heard the door go in, and screams, when my wife and I came down.

GEORGE SIMPSON (Policeman L 149). I was called to 56, Belvedere Road at 12.45 on 14th August—I asked prisoner what was the matter—he said "I don't know, you can go in and see"—another constable went in—I took the prisoner to the station; he was charged with assaulting these women—he said nothing.

GEORGE FREDERICK COOPER . On 13th August I was house surgeon at St. Thomas's Hospital—three women were brought there—I examined Susannah Fisher; she had a Wound over her left eyebrow, and another on the top scalp on the left side, each about an inch long—she was covered with blood—She came in her nightdress—the wounds had bled pretty freely—I was shown the mallet at the police-court; I saw blood marts upon it—I also saw Mrs. Lee—she had a slight wound upon her head, and her arm was broken—Ellen Lee had two wounds on the' top of the scalp, one going down to the bone, and a large bruise behind, her right eat; she was partly unconscious—all the wounds might have been caused by the mallet produced.
HENRY BARKER (Policeman L 100). I assisted the women into a cab to go to the hospital—I found this mallet on the parlour drawer; it was marked with wet blood.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence said that he was driven to it, by the women's conduct. He had been to Brighton and round the coast to look for work, and when he came, home there was nothing to sleep on, the bed was locked up in a corner, and when he asked to be let in the sister told him he had no business there, so he burst the door open, but did not know what he did after that.

div1.p:
GUILTY . There were two other indictments against the prisoner for assaults upon the other women.—
Five Years' Penal Servitude.

963.
EDWARD WITHALL (41)
, Feloniously marrying
Louis Simpson during the life of his wife.

p.hi: There being no proof that the prisoner knew of his wife's existence within seven years of the second marriage, the Jury were directed to return a verdict of

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

963A.
JOHN FULLER (35)
,
PLEADED GUILTY to burglary in the dwelling-house of
William Thomas and stealing seven silver spoon and other goods.

964.
JOHN FULLER was again indicted
for bearking and entering the dwelling-house of
Henry Charlesworth Underwood and stealing five rings and other goods, the property of Henry Charles-worth Underwood and another.

HENRY GEORGE (Detective V). I had the prisoner in custody on another charge of burglary on 11th August—he was searched, and duplicates were given to me to make inquiries about—I served the prisoner in the House of Detention with notice of this charge—he said "The watch and chain you are speaking of belong to my father and mother, who had it for years; it is an heirloom, of our family."
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. Two duplicates were found on you.
DALEY FUSSELL (Policeman V 220). I had the prisoner in custody on another charge—I searched him and found these spoons and these two duplicates in his left-hand trousers pocket.

EDWARD GARDNER . I am assistant to Mr. Amhurst, a pawnbroker, of York Street, Westminster—this duplicate of 26th July, 1884, is from our shop—it is for a silver watch and Albert, pawned for 9s. to the best of my belief by the prisoner.

JOHN LONG . I am Mr. Underwood's son-in-law, and reside with him at 42, Kearsley Street, Battersea—on the night of 25th July I closed and bolted up the house—all the fastenings were secure—the following morning I found everything ransacked—an entrance had been effected by the latch of the back window being pushed back and the window being opened—of my own property I missed some links and an old cruet stand of solid silver, a silver shield with a cornet and a cricket bat, some rings, and a pearl necklace—the value of the property missing was about 30l.—the silver chain is my mother's; it was in the house that night—I produce a photograph of it.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. The chain is peculiar, having one long link and the others different, the circumference being alike.

WILHELMINA WORNAST . I was in Mr. Underwood's service—this is my watch (produced)—it has a private mark inside where it was put up for sale—it was safe in the house on the night of 26th May—the chain belongs to my mistress.

Prisoner's Defence. That watch has been in our family 20 years, my father gave it to my brother three months before he died. I have no relations and no witnesses to prove it. What the last witness has said is utterly false.

965.
JOHN KILSEY (35)
, Stealing 1l. 16s., the money of
Thomas Speller. Second Count, receiving the same.
MR. WARBURTON Prosecuted; MR. LILLEY Defence.

THOMAS SPELLER . I am a warehouseman, of 25, Queen Elizabeth Street—the prisoner lives at No. 26—Rebecca Saunders, my niece, was my servant for six months—I had 36s. in a bag in my bed room, there was a half-sovereign and some silver and copper—I left it in a cupboard in a the box on Sunday as I was going into the country—I came back on be Monday night, Bank Holiday, and the girl was not there—on Thurs
day night, about 8 o'clock, I found the bag empty and the drawer still locked—I had arranged with the girl to follow me down on Bank Holi
day—I sent for the police—when I saw the prisoner in custody he said Tom, you are not going to charge me?"—I said "Yes, I am, Jim"—I charged him because I had learned that the girl went away with him.
Cross-examined. When I charged him he said "I never took it"—I gave my niece 3s. a week, and I gave her 2s. to follow me and her aunt into the country.

ROBERT LONG SANDERSON . I live at 25, Queen Elizabeth Street, and am the father of Rebecca Sanderson—on Monday, 4th August, Bank Holiday, I went home between 4 and 5 o'clock and put the key in the private door and tried it once or twice—I then heard a step and my daughter came down and unbolted the door—I went upstairs and found the prisoner lying on her bed—I said "Come out, you scoundrel, you vagabond"—we had some words and he went away—I then beat my daughter, and she ran out—the prisoner brought her back at a quarter or half-past 2 a.m.—on the Tuesday my wife and her sister gave the prisoner a good beating, and my daughter ran away again on the Tuesday.

Cross-examined. My wife was in the country when I beat my daughter—when the prisoner brought her back my wife and her sister flew at him and gave him a sound thrashing—my daughter and I had lived comfortably together—her age is 16—the prisoner is a married man.

REBECCA SANDERSON . I am the wife of the last witness—on 4th August, Bank Holiday, I went to Hipping with the prisoner and his wife—we went to a public-house—my daughter remained at home—I was present when the prisoner brought her home at 2.30—I went out next day about 3 p.m. leaving her there, and when I returned she was gone and I did not see her till she was fetched from Epping—I asked the prisoner where he had left her; he said that he would not tell me—I said "If you do tell me I will not lock you up"—he said "I would rather break your arm or your wrist than tell you where she is."
Cross-examined. He said that he would rather suffer six months—I was charging him with running away with my daughter, and likewise with stealing the money.

REBECCA SARAH SANDERSON . I live with my father and mother—on Sunday morning, 30th of August, my uncle went away and returned on Monday night—on the Tuesday my father and uncle went out to work early as usual—the prisoner had come to the house on Monday the 4th and he and I went upstairs together—my father came home about 4.30 that afternoon, and the shop was closed—some one had locked the side
door, I do not know who—only me and the prisoner were in the house, there was no one to lock it but him—it is my uncle's house, but my father also lives there—about three weeks before that I had a conversation with the prisoner at his door—he said "Have you any money?"—I said "No"—he said "Could you get any?"—I said "I don't know"—I had no more conversation with him till I took the money; I then ran away with him—I met him in the Kent Road and told him I had taken the money and gave it to him—we went in a tram and he told me to take it back, that I must not have it, but I did not, and we went for a walk, and I was with him all day and all night—I did not go home next day, I was with him; I afterwards went to my aunt's—I only had one shilling of the money, but he bought my railway ticket—I was convicted of stealing the money and had a month's imprisonment.

Cross-examined. He knew I was in service with my uncle, I did not say was paid, but he knew it—he is a lighterman and lives next door—I pleaded guilty before the Magistrate—my month is not up—the Treasury

Solicitor spoke to me last Monday—they fetched me out and told me to come here as a witness for Kilsey—I did not hand this money to Kilsey for our joint expenses, I told him where I took it from—he told me to take it back, but he did not give it to me—we were taken in custody immediately I returned home and charged with another offence—I did not spend money as well as he when together, I had none—I did not ask him to spend it—when he asked me if I wanted anything I said "Yes."

MARY ANN SHIPGOOD . My husband is a carman, of 5, Greg Street, Waterloo Road—we were in the Battersea Road on the Wednesday after Bank Holiday and saw the girl Sanderson and the prisoner in a tramcar going away from their home.

JOHN HAIG (Detective Officer). On August 8th I was on duty at Ber
mondsey Station when Sanderson was brought in—no money was found on her—the prisoner was already there—the charge was read to him of being concerned with the girl in stealing 36s., the money of her uncle—he said "I deny the charge."
Cross-examined. No effort was made to charge him with the abduction of the girl—I got a certificate by the order of the Treasury to ascertain her age.

p.hi: The prisoner in his statement before the Magistrate said that he saw the gril in the Kent Rood, who said she had some vermin powder and said she would take it if he did not go with her, as she would not go home any more, after which they took a lodging.

on the Second Count.—
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

div1.p:
966.
JOHN ALEXANDER (33)
, Robbery with violence on
Thomas Joyce, and stealing a watch and chain, his property.

MR. MONTAGU WILLIAMS
Prosecuted; MR. POYNTER Defended.

WILLIAM SINGING . I am a cafe manager at 8, Nelson Square, Black
friars—on Sunday, 27th July, I saw two men dodging the prosecutor in St. George's Circus, the prisoner was one—he had on a black coat, as he has now—one of them said "Go to the first turning on the left, go down there"—they both ran in that direction, and Joyce followed them—Joyce afterwards complained to me.
Cross-examined. I feel sure the prisoner is one of the two men, I saw his face before he ran away.

THOMAS JOYCE . I am a dairyman, of 20, V. Block, Peabody Square, Blackfriars—on 27th July I was going down St. George's Circus with a parcel in one hand and an umbrella in the other—as I passed the prisoner he gave me a winder and snatched my watch and chain—I saw my watch lying near me, but could not go after it, as I was winded—the prisoner picked it up—I went after him, and another chap got in front of me and "said "What is the matter?" and prevented my following him—I spoke to a policeman, and next night I saw the prisoner among 13 others at the Borough Road Police-station—he is the man who stopped me and took my watch—I picked him out, and he said "It was not me, it was a man like me, I know the man who has the watch"—no one pulled my coat to point him out—there is a gaslight at the spot.
Cross-examined. Murrell asked me on Sunday night what clothes the man wore, and I told him—the prisoner was taken on Monday, and Murrell said that he had taken a man on suspicion—I am sure the
prisoner is the man, I don't know whether he had a collar on—I knew him at the station, Murrell did not point him out.

GEORGE MURRELL (Policeman M 394). I saw the prisoner running in Warwick Street with a crowd of 40 or 50 behind him, no one was in front—he ran up close to me and said "Have you seen the man who stole a watch by here?"—I said "You vagabond, it was you"—he began to swear, and before I could get hold of him he got through the mob and got away—I took him on the Monday and said it was for stealing a watch last night—he said "Why did you not take me then?"—I said "I could not get you"—he said at the station "I did not steal his watch, but I know who did."

Cross-examined. I may have told the Magistrate that, or I may not—he said "This is the thanks a man gets for assisting the police"—(the words "Why did you not take me then?" did not appear in the deposi
tions)—Joyce gave me a description of the prisoner's coat on the Sunday—the prisoner's mother has given me no information.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I did not pull Joyce by his coat tail—a cabman who had been robbed was brought in at the same time to see if he could identify any one.
GUILTY .

He then
PLEADED GUILTY** to a conviction at Newington in March, 1876, when he was sentenced to Ten Years' Penal Servitude.—
Twelle Months' Hard Labour, to commence after the termination of his former sentence.

967.
GEORGE LEE (42)
, Robbery with violence on
William Brooks, and stealing a watch, a seal, a watch-key, and part of a chain, his property.

WILLIAM BROOKS . I keep a shop at 23, Lower Park Road, Peckham—on the 21st of July I walking down New Kent Road with my wife—the prisoner came from behind in front of us, hit me on my mouth, pulled out my watch, and broke the chain—I cried out—he ran off—I went to the station and gave information—I saw the prisoner with others and picked him out—I also saw my watch, which was found on him.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I did not say to the sergeant "I don't know him, perhaps my wife may know him better."
SARAH BROOKS . I was with my husband, and saw the prisoner come up and take his watch—I picked him out from four others at the station—he is the man.
Cross-examined. You had no hat on nor had the others.
GEORGE MURRELL (Policeman M 394). On the 22nd of July, at 1.15, I took the prisoner on another charge—he took this watch from his pocket.

Prisoner's Defence. I was at the Crown public-house, at the corner of Lambeth Road, when a party who is in custody brought me the I watch and asked me to sell it for him. When I was taken to the station I was put with four others, and the policeman knocked my hat off. The prosecutor said "I don't know that man, but my wife does;" and then I she said, "That is the man who robbed my husband."
GUILTY .

He then
PLEADED GUILTY** to at conviction at this Court in February, 1883.—
Ten Years' Penal Servitude.

968.
DANIEL DWYER (44) and
FREDERICK GREENHILL (20)
, Unlawfully attempting to break into the dwelling-house of
Augustus Bruchmann, also having housebreaking implements in their possession.
MR. BLACKWELL Prosecuted; MR. LILLEY appeared for Greenhill.

JAMES SCOTT (Detective W). On 3rd September, about 9.30 p.m., I saw the prisoners in Brixton Road loitering outside the Prince of Wales—I was with W 409; we were both in plain clothes—the prisoners then went to the Black Horse, Brixton Road, and then to the White Horse, and about 11.30 they went up the Angell Road to No. 53, that leads into the Brixton Road—they entered the front garden through the gate, and we concealed ourselves in a garden on the other side of the way, and lost sight of them, and then we saw Greenhill on the top of a wall between 53 and 51—he disappeared into the garden of 51, and in a few minutes a dog barked, and Dwyer whistled and ran out of the garden of 53, and I lost sight of him for that night—I have no doubt whatever that he is the man—I had been watching them over two hours—I went into the garden of 53, and saw Greenhill on the top of the wall coming towards me, with this jimmy in his hand—I stepped back, he dropped the jimmy on top of the wall and leaped over Peddar's head into the garden of 51, and was going out at the gate when Keats stopped him—he struggled very violently—Peddar went to Keats's assistance, and he kicked him and knocked him down—I went to Keats's assistance—Greenhill struggled so violently that I had to strike him with my staff—we then overpowered him and took him to the station—on the morning of 6th September I went to 413, Cold Harbour Lane—I saw Dwyer there, and told him what I had come for—he said "I know nothing whatever about it"—on the way to the station he asked what time the job occurred—I said "About 11.30"—he said "I was home about 9.30, and in bed about 10 o'clock."
Cross-examined by Dwyer. I saw you leave the Black Horse and go for a few yards towards your house.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Numbers 51 and 53 are occupied, they are houses of some size, and servants are kept—it was rather a fine evening—there were no lamps in the back gardens nor in the front—at the time of the struggle one of us was in each garden and the other in the street, but close in contact—he did not fall when I struck him—I found this jimmy on the top of the wall.
Re-examined. There are plenty of lamps in front of the public-houses.

ALBERT PEDDAR (Policeman 409). I was with Scott—I have heard his account, and agree with it—I went to Keats's assistance; and Greenhill kicked me on my leg and knocked me down—I have no doubt that Dwyer is the man who was in the garden of No. 53.
Cross-examined by Dwyer. I followed you down the Brixton Road.
Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. No. 51 is occupied, No. 53 is not—it is not my regular beat.

RICHARD KEATS (Policeman W R 7). On 3rd September I was on duty in plain clothes and joined the two other officers about 11 o'clock—I saw the prisoners go down the Brixton Road to the White Horse—they after
wards went up Angell Road into the front garden of 53, which is un
occupied, and shortly afterwards Dwyer came out, and I lost sight of him—we all crossed over then to No. 51, which is next door to 53—Greenhill jumped from the wall between the two houses and ran towards the gate, and I caught him just as he was coming out—he was very
violent, and struggled—I searched him at the station, and found in his left coat-pocket this piece of candle and a box of matches.

Cross-examined by Dwyer. I have known you about six years, but I let three days go by before I went to your house because I did not know exactly where you lived, and had forgotten your name till the other prisoner mentioned it, but I knew you very well by sight—you have not got your name on your door.

CHARLOTTE FRANKLIN . I am an ironer, of 17, Mordant Street, Stock
well—on Wednesday night, 3rd September, about 9 o'clock, I saw the two prisoners and another man in Ferndale Road—Dwyer said "There are two servants in the house and the people are out of town"—I went on and afterwards saw them again, and heard Dwyer say "Don't be a fool, it is a crack job."
Cross-examined by Dwyer. I don't know the, third man, I have not seen him since—it was dark, but I can swear, to your voice—I am engaged to Greenhill, and walk out with him.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. I have known Greenhill three years, and have walked out with him about two years; I always found him to be a well-conducted honest young man, or I should not have walked out with him.

SAMUEL MARSH (Police Inspector W). On 3rd September I was in the station when Greenhill was brought in and charged with attempting to break and enter 51, Angell Road—he said "I never had that jemmy; a man asked me to go with him, and when you came, up he ran away; I am had for nothing"—I examined 53, Angell Road, and found the side garden door forced, and there were marks of the jimmy which had ben inserted in the frame and the door forced open—I examined No. 51, and found that the same instrument had been used for the upper part of the kitchen door—I fitted it; the upper end of it had been used near the lock—Dwyer was brought in at 1.20 a.m. on the 6th—I took down his statement; he said "It is false; I had a row with a man outside the Black Horse, with a thin young man, at about 9.30; he wanted me to lend him a hammer; I do not know his name. I don't care what you say, I swear I know nothing about it. I was home 10.30; my wife said 'You are late, I thought you were coming home at 9 o'clock'"—when I read the charge over to him he made no reply—he was arrested at his house—Cold Harbour Lane is about ten minutes walk from Angell Road, and about two minutes' walk from the Black Horse, where he was seen by Scott.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. A constable brought this jimmy to the station, and I took it with me when I examined No. 51 and 53—I shall have been twenty years in the force next January—I have no knowledge of these jimmies being made and sold by the gross.

AUGUSTUS BEUCHMANN . I live at 51, Angell Road, Brixton—on 3rd September I went to bed a little past; 11 p.m.—I was aroused between 11.30 and 11.45, and the police came inside and made me examine the door; there were marks on it—I lost nothing.

Dwyer's Statement before the Magistrate. "I met them about 9 o'clock. I have known this one four years, but I don't know the other. We walked from the Prince of Wales to the Black Horse. I met two or three I know, and had a glass or two. We went out; I said I was going home, and the three of us walked as far as Leyton's the baker's, where I said ‘Good

night,' and they crossed the road and I went towards home. As far as loitering on my way, some niggers were playing there, and men were dancing, drunk. I spoke to a young man about it, and he walked with me to within three or four doors of my house, and I went on. Going in in I met my next door neighbour coming, and I passed directly by him and stood talking at the door with him, and I went in and went straight to bed. I never saw the man again till I saw him in the House of Deten
tion; this man can prove I am not the man if he likes to say so."

WILLIAM OTTEWELL . I am a labourer, of Back Lane, Brixton—I know Dwyer—on Wednesday night, 3rd September, about 11.5, I saw him outside the Atlantic in Cold Harbour Lane looking at some niggers—it was five or ten minutes past 11 when he left—he said he was going indoors; my uncle lives near there—I am sure about the time because I started from the Old Kent Road Station about 11.20, and arrived at Loughborough Park soon afterwards.
Cross-examined. The Atlantic is about; three minutes' walk from the Black Horse.

JOSEPH FRIEDLAND . I live at 415, Cold Harbour Lane, and am a bookbinder—on 3rd September, about 11.30, I was going out of the next door house to Mr. Dwyer, and saw his door in the act of shutting—I stood talking to him I dare say ten minutes, certainly more than five minutes—he went into his own house at 11.10—that is about 100 yards from the Atlantic or perhaps more; it is about; three minutes' walk—somebody said "Good night," but I do not know whether it was at the right side of the house or the left—there is a shrubbery between our garden and his, and an outer house—I should not like to say whose voice it was.
Cross-examined. It might be two minutes later than 11.10, I said about 11 before the Magistrate—it would take seven or eight minutes to walk from there to the Angell Road.

MISS DWYER. I am the prisoner's daughter and live with him—on the 3rd of September I went up to bed between 1030 and 11, I had not gone to bed when I heard my father pass my bedroom door, and I said "Good night;" that was soon after eleven.
Cross-examined. I should think it was about 11.20, I went to sleep some time afterwards—my father would not have to pass through my room if he went out again.

p.hi: Dwyer in his defence stated that he went straight home from the Black Horse, and had no idea in what part of the Angell Road the house was; that he had known Greenhill four years, and he was a respectable young man, but he did not know the others.

div1.p:
GEEENHILL—
GUILTY .—
Six Months' Hard Labour.

DWYER—
NOT GUITLY .

969.
BLACKMANN GANN (33)
, Feloniously wounding
Eliza Prior, with intent to murder. Second Count, to do her grievous bodily harm.
MR. BAYLISS Prosecuted; MR. GOODRICH Defended.
ELIZA PRIOR . I lodge in Peckham—on the 7th August I lived at 51, Royal Road, Kennington, and was working at tie Oxford and Cambridge Laundry, Albany Road, Oamberwell—I was living with the

prisoner as his wife, but had left him two days—on the morning of the 7th he came into the ironing room where I was—he was very kind and asked if I would go back and live with him—it might be about one o'clock—I said I would not—he told me his landlady had committed an assault on him, and he had taken out a summons against her—I was then starching some collars, and I felt my neck bleeding, and I called out—it must have been the second time that he came up to me—I could not tell you what took place—the first time he put his arm round my neck, as I thought to kiss me, and I put my hand up and felt the blood trickling down my neck—it must have been about ten minutes after he took his arm away—one of the women said "You have got a cut on your neck"—and he said after, to the constable, he must have used the knife—he made no ✗ats to me—he said nothing to me about my life—he never once threaned my life since I have known him;. not to me—I was examined before the Magistrate—I do not know whether what I said was taken down or not, of head over to me; I have not the slightest recollection—all I know is to statement he made to the constable, that he used the knife—y✗, he said. he thought I was cohabiting with the master at the laundry—he did not say what he would do to me if I did—not to me, neither have I made such a statement—I would not tell you an untruth if I knew it—I have said the prisoner came into the ironing room about 1.15 and said he wished to speak to me—I said "I will have nothing to do with you"—he did not say "If you do not come with me you shall have no other man, for I will take your b——y life"—I never made that statement, not that I know of—I could not swear it—I do not remember saying so, really—I saw a knife afterwards—I did not see him open the knife—I had a scratch on my thumb and I thought it was only on the thumb—I did not say he had come to take my life—I do not remember, in the agitation of the moment, what I said or what I did—the Divisional Surgeon saw me.

Cross-examined. I had lived with the prisoner about 18 months, during which time he was a kind good man to me and my children, except when he got a drop of drink, which he did now and then, and it made him like an insane person—when he came to me on the 7th August he was beastly drunk—the wound was very slight and did not prevent my going on with my work—I should not have taken notice of it if he had not come back with the constable.
By the COURT. I do not remember him saying he wished it had gone through my heart; he might have said it to the constable, but not to me.

GEORGE HOLLIS (Policeman P 121). About 1.30 in the afternoon of the 7th August the prisoner came to me at Camberwell Gate and said he had stabbed a woman at the laundry in Albany Road—he was very much excited, but not drunk—I went back with him and another constable, and went to the ironing room at the laundry, where I saw the last witness, and she said in his presence she had been stabbed, and she should charge him with it, and he said "I wish it had gone through her b——heart "I was given this knife (produced)—the prosecutrix said it was done with this knife, and I took him to the station—on his way he said he wished it had gone to her b——heart, and that would be an end of her—the other constable wrote it down.
HANNAH DOLPHIA . I am a laundress, of 205, Abbey Sreet, Bemondsey,

and did work at the Oxford and Cambridge Laundry—I was there on the day in question, when the prisoner came, at about 11.30 a.m., to the bottom of the stairs and called the prosecutrix by the name of "Tits"—she said she did not wish to have anything to do with him, and wished he would go away and leave her alone—he said "I won't keep you a minute if you will come and speak one word"—he came up into the laundry—he was begging her forgiveness and asking her pardon, and with that I went downstairs and left them to themselves—when I was downstairs the prosecutrix screamed, and I went up and she said he had stabbed her with a knife, but I did not see anything of that or the knife—I went downstairs and said to the employer "I wish you would put Mr. Gann out, for I cannot work, and I shall go home"—he said he would, and he called him down, and he was down there talking till about 1.15, and then he came upstairs again and asked her if he should get her any dinner—she went to starch some collars, and he went up to her and put his arm round her neck—he asked her to forgive him, and she said she would not—she screamed, but I did not pay any attention to that—she screamed a second time, and I went over and found she was bleeding very much—the prisoner had this old knife in his hand; it had a piece broken off—then he made a second attempt, and broke a second piece off—I did not see him strike her with the knife the first time—I said "Mr. Gann, you have been and stabbed her," and he said "Yes, I have stabbed her; I wish it was to her b——heart; if you take her part I will serve you the same"—I went away to fetch a policeman, and left them to themselves—I could not see how her shoulder was struck—he had the knife with the blade downwards—I went out to fetch a policeman, and when I came back he was standing out in the street asking for a lucifer, and I said to a man "Don't talk to him, he has stabbed his wife," and he said "No, my wife is in there cohabiting with the proprietor of the Oxford and Cambridge Laundry"—I used this knife for my dinner—I did not see how it broke—it must have broken in his hand, because it was whole before—he was very drunk—he was very good and kind when he was not drunk, and he used to bring her nice dinners—I did not see any blood—the prosecutrix did not seem affected by it.

HENRY MORRIS SIMMONS . I am a surgeon, of 66, Camberwell Road—I saw the prosecutrix at about 3 o'clock on the day in question—I found a very slight wound on the left shoulder and a cut on the right side of the neck, about one inch long but of no depth, just severing the skin—it was such a wound as might be produced by this knife—the wound was recent—I thought the blow might have been sharply given, but just the broken angle have caught her and divided the skin, and it being stated to be an entire knife before, I looked at the fracture in the knife—I thought it was an old cracked place, and the blow on the shoulder had been produced with the back of the knife, which had doubled under the impetus of the blow, and the knife had broken up.

The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate. "She has been rather cool to me lately and I have been drinking, and when I am drunk I do not know what I do. I did not intend to hurt her, only to frighten her."

p.hi:
of unlawfully wounding.—
Four Months' Hard Labour.

div1.p:
970.
GEORGE JAMES TOWNSEND (34)
, Feloniously wounding
Rosina Squires, with intent to murder. Second Count, with intent to do grievous bodily harm.

ROSINA SQUIRES . I live at 1, Royal Tent Court, Tabard Street, Borough—I ani single—for some time I have been living with the prisoner—I work at cleaning and charing—the prisoner used to work at odd jobs when he could get them—we occupied one room—on the 2nd of July, about 3 or 4 in the afternoon, I was in my room with Elizabeth Gorman—I had been out all day, with the prisoner and Gorman, since five minutes to 5 in the morning drinking on and off at different public-houses—I left the prisoner in the Waterloo Road and went home about 4 or half-past—the prisoner came into the room and asked me for some money—I said "Lie down and have a sleep and you shall have some more drink when you get up"—he quarrelled with me and tried to take the money out of my hand—I had 1s. 10 1/2 d. in my hand—he struck me and Gorman said if he struck me again she should strike him—I and Gorman then laid down to have a sleep—I don't know what happened after that; he went away—I don't know where he went to, I did not see him go out—when I went to sleep he was doing something in the room, I don't know what; I believe he was packing up some things belonging to him—I don't remember anything else till I was taken to the hospital—before that, while I was oh the bed, I leaned over to cough, I could not cough, and I found that my throat was cut—Gorman was then asleep on the same bed—the prisoner had two razors; he was not in the room then—I got out of bed and got to the window; I had a quart can on the window ledge and I knocked it oh the window ledge and beckoned to James Sexton, who was looking out of a window opposite, and he came over—I can't say whether he helped me to the hospital—I did not; cut my own throat—I have a proof to give that I did not do it myself, there is my hat for one thing that he damaged in the first place; he cut it right across and then he made a wound on my shoulder, before he attempted to out my throat.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You were not indoors when I and Gorman came in, you came in afterwards—you twisted my fingers to take the money out of my hand, and you hurt me—I will say nothing to hurt you, if you will say nothing to hurt yourself—we quarrelled over the money.
By the COURT. I am 25 years of age—I have been living with the prisoner 12 months—he had work; he is a farrier I believe.

JAMES SEXTON . I am a labourer, and live at 12, Royal Tent Court, just opposite No. 1—on the evening of the 2nd of July, about 6.15, I was looking out of the garret window and saw the prosecutrix knocking two or three times on the window ledge with a tin can in her hand, and saw that she had her throat out—about five or six minutes before that I saw the prisoner come out of the passage of No. 1; he walked down the court and walked away, with a bundle in his hand tied up in a red hand
kerchief—I ran over to No. 1 and saw Mrs. Lloyd and Mrs. Squires and spoke to them.

MARY ANN SQUIRES . I live at No. 1, Royal Tent Court, in the front-room downstairs—my husband is a labourer—I am no relation to the prosecutrix—between 3 and 4 o'clock that afternoon she and Gorman came home and went upstairs to their room, the top garret—I don't know where the prisoner was then, he must have been upstairs; I never saw him till he came downstairs with a bundle at 10 minutes past 6—Ellen

Lloyd was sitting on the doorstep, and she said to him "How did your face come scratched?"—he said "Hush, the old woman upstairs," and he opened his coat and showed blood on the front of his shirt—he said "Let me look?"—he said "Hush"—he ran upstairs and got the bundle tied in a reel handkerchief—he was not upstairs above half a minute, he then went down the court and I saw no more of him—about half a minute afterwards James Sexton came over and spoke to me, and Lloyd said "For God's sake go upstairs"—Lloyd went up first and I followed almost directly—I went into the prisoner's room and there saw Rosina Squires sitting on a chair with her throat cut and bleeding—I ran down as quick as I could and got the police to come—I saw a razor on the side of the chair she was sitting—she fell off the chair and I picked up the razor; it was shut—the handle was broken and the blade was about three-parts up in blood—when the policeman came Lloyd gave him the razor.
Cross-examined. When I said "How came the blood on your shirt," you said "Mrs. Gorman hit me with something."
ELLEN LLOYD (Examined by the Prisoner). I spoke to you first, I asked who scratched your face and you said "Hush"—you pulled off your coat and showed me the blood in front of your shirt.

LOUISA PATEY . I am single, and live at No. 1, Royal Tent Court—I remember Rosina Squires going but with the prisoner about half-past 7 on the morning of this occurrence—the prisoner came, back at 2 o'clock—the prosecutrix came back about 4 o'clock, and went upstairs—after that I heard quarrelling about money—she said, "Give me my money,' and he said, "I will crack your neck"—soon after that somebody told me something, and I went up into their room and found the woman with her throat cut and bleeding—before that It saw the prisoner go down the court with a bundle in his hand—he came home again about 4 o'clock next morning, and I went for a constable and gave him in custody.

JAMES FARRER (Policeman M 186). On the evening of 2nd july, about a quarter past 6, I was called to the prisoner's house by James Saxton—I went upto the top room front, and sent the prosecutrix there lying near a pool of blood—I at once sent for Dr. Bedford to attend to her, and she was removed in an ambulance to the hospital—I saw Elizabeth Gorman in the room—she was examined before the Magistrate—she was in bed asleep when I went into the room; I awoke her; "she appeared to be drunk—I saw this razor in the room, and took possession of it; there was wet blood on it.

ROBERT STEELE (Policeman M 132). On the morning of 3rd July, about 4 o'clock, the witness Patey came and spoke to me—I went to the corner of the court, and saw the prisoner standing there—I said, "I want you"—he, said,' "Don't be in a hurry, old man, I will go with you"—I said, "I want you for cutting a woman's throat last night"—he made no reply—I took him to the station, and after the charge was read over to him he said, "I shan't deny what I have done"—he was wearing two shirts; they were both covered with blood, the right wristband more particularly—I was before the Magistrate, and heard Elizabeth Gorman examined as a witness—the prisoner had the opportunity of cross
examining her—I went to St. Saviour's Infirmary, walworth, last Tuesday, and there saw Gorman ill in bed—she seemed to be very ill indeed—Mr. Grose, the medical superintendent, attended her.

CHARLES GROSE . I am medical superintendent of St. Seviour's In
firmary,

Walworth—Elizabeth Gorman was admitted as a patient there last Monday, the 15th—I have seen her this morning—she is still in the infirmary suffering from severe inflammation of the throat and quinsey—it would be very dangerous for her to come here and give evidence; her life is in danger—she is unable to travel or to give evidence.

The deposition of Elizabeth Gorman was read as follows: "I live at 1, Wallis Alley, Mint Street; I used to live at 1, Royal Tent Court; I lived there on 2nd July. I am single. On 2nd July Rosina Squires and I went out just before 5 in the morning—she lived in the same house. The prisoner had not slept there on the night of the 1st. Rosina and I went out drinking together. About 9 a.m. we were in the Victoria Tavern, Waterloo Road. We had met the prisoner shortly after 5 o'clock in the Borough; he had been drinking with us; we went into the Victoria Tavern. Some altercation took place between him and Rosina about some money she had in her hand; he wanted to take it from her; she resisted doing so, she scratched his face; he struck her. I joined in the quarrel, and I struck him on the head with a pork bone and made his head bleed; he bled very much, and it ran down his shirt. After the quarrel Rosina and I went away, leaving the prisoner outside the house. Me and Rosina continued on the drink. I don't know how we got home. When I woke up I found myself in Rosina's Squire's bed. She was near the door, rolling on the floor in a pool of blood. The doctor, two policemen, and others were there."

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. "I told you when you struck her not to do it again or I should hit you, for she did not deserve it—I was not eating the pork with your knife—I did not say I would chiv you."

CHARLES MAYER . I was house-surgeon at Guy's Hospital on 2nd July when Rosina Squires was brought there shortly after 7 p.m.—I examined her—she had a clean cut wound about five inches long across the front of the neck, the windpipe was open, and the cut was deeper towards the right side—there was also a clean cut wound an inch long on the top of the right shoulder; that was quite superficial, and a slight cut on the back of the head—that was not recent—the other two wounds were quite recent—there were some old bruises on the right arm and left side—the wounds were such as might have been inflicted by a razor—I saw blood on the razor, it was shown to me at the police-court—her life was in danger for some time; she was not able to attend before the Magistrate till the 1st of August—she is quite out of danger now.

p.hi: The prisoner in a long defence stated that he and the two women were out all day together drinking at different public-houses; that a quarrel arose between him and Elizabeth Gorman, who struck him and scratched his face, and threatened him with a knife; that he went home, and words occurred, and he left, and was not aware of what occurred afterwards, and that he was entirely innocent of injuring the prosecutrix.

on Second Count.—
Seven Years' Penal Servitude.

div1.p:
971.
ARTHUR WITHEY (25) was indicted
for, and charged on the Coroner's Inquisition with, feloniously killing and slaying
Alice Swan.
MESSRS. POLAND and MONTAGU WILLIAMS. Prosecuted; MR. GRIFFITHS
Defended.
FANNY SWAN . My husband's name is James—I live at 15, Webb

Street, Bermondsey—I had a little girl four years old named Alice; I was out with her on Tuesday, 2nd September, just after 4 in the after
noon—they were doing some repairs at a school there as I was passing by—my little girl had hold of my hand; she was next to the wall—I heard a woman scream—I looked up and saw a pail falling close on my head—I dodged my head away—the next thing I saw was my little child on the ground insensible—she had been struck by the pail—it was a zinc pail, an empty one—the child was taken to the hospital, and she subsequently died—there was no scaffolding on the pathway, I did not notice any.

WILLIAM STANLEY . I live at 19, St. John's Place, Bermondsey; I am a costermonger—on Tuesday I was at the corner of Webb Street at about twenty minutes to 5—I saw some buckets being drawn up and down at the Board School—I saw one bucket go up and down—it was fastened on to a hook—I only noticed one hook; the pail was hanging on that—I saw the pail start from the platform of the scaffolding—I saw the prisoner there—it was let down by a rope and a pulley; it came down very slowly—I did not see who was at the bottom—when it got about 10 yards it struck against a pole—the prisoner started it from the top—he put the pail on the hook and it struck the pole and tilted the pail off the hook—I saw it fall, and it touched the wall and struck the child on the head.

By the COURT. If the pail had gone down all right it would have gone inside the school premises—there was no high wind blowing at the time that I noticed—it came down all right till it struck the piece of project
ing scaffolding—I did not take notice afterwards whether the prisoner was lowering the bucket, I ran towards the child—I noticed afterwards that the buckets were properly lowered, with the chain properly fastened round them, properly hooked.

Cross-examined. There was no hoarding there except the wall—this building stands back in a recess, back from the wall—the prisoner was standing between sixty and seventy feet from the ground—I will not swear that there were not two hooks on the pail—I saw a bucket full of asphalte go up—I saw a man named Avery pulling it up; he was over the other side of the wall—I could see enough to see that it was being pulled up by a rope by some one from the bottom, but I could not see if the same man that pulled it up lowered it down—I saw the pail go up and the prisoner lowered it—I could not undertake to say that there was not a gust of wind.

JEREMIAH GILHAM . I am a labourer employed by the Asphalte Com
pany—I live at 33, Kell Street, Borough—on the day in question I was at work in the Board School at Webb Street—it is not my duty to fill the pails at the top, I stand close by the pails at the bottom—I make the stuff ready to put in the pails, and then Avery wound them up to the prisoner, and the prisoner then lets them down again—I saw the pail coming down and saw it come into collision with what we call a puddick, and immediately fell—I could not say from where I was standing whether the chain was round the handle or through the hook before it struck anything—it was coming down steadily.

Cross-examined. The prisoner has worked for our firm between six and seven years—I have worked with him before, and always found him to be a steady careful fellow; I never knew him to have a pint of beer—

I have lost one eye—this is a very high building—the prisoner had to act under the orders of the foreman, Mr. Blake, and we have to work with the tools that are supplied to us by the builders—if the pail came in contact with anything the hook would fall out of the ring—50 buckets might have fallen and fallen inside if they did not strike against anything in coming down.

JOHN AVERY . I live at 32, Charles Street, Oakley Street, Lambeth, and am a labourer in the employ of the Val de Travers Asphalte Com
pany—on this Tuesday I was at work at the bottom of the Scaffolding, inside the enclosure—I had pulled up a pail full by the pulley, the prisoner would have to empty it and let down the empty pail—there is a scaffolding up above, with a scaffold-pole with a pulley, for the purpose of being worked; I saw the empty bucket hanging over, it was lifted over the boards and gently lowered—there is a difference between lifting it over and throwing it over—I did not say I saw the pail thrown over—when it was lifted off the boards he did not call to me below—I was on the look-out—I was lowering it—I lowered it about 15 or 20 feet, and it then struck against a scaffolding-pole and fell over, I called "Below"—I could not see if the chain was round the handle, it was too far up—a careful man would put both hooks through the ring—the bucket fell directly it touched the scaffolding—it is a zinc pail, about 20 lb. weight.

Cross-examined. We were only using one hook, I was at the bottom, and it is impossible for me to say whether the chain was round the handle or not—I have been with this Company, off and on, for two years—the prisoner is a steady, hard-working, respectable fellow, and very careful—all he had to do was to take off the full bucket, put on the empty one, tilt it over the ground, and then I lowered it with the rope.

THOMAS FORD (Policeman M 73). I was Coroner's Officer at the inquest—I saw the prisoner there; he was sworn—I heard him give his evidence—after the verdict I arrested him on the Coroner's warrant—he was bailed.

The Prisoner's Defence before the Coroner. "On Tuesday last I was asphalting the top of the school in Webb Street; we were using iron pails. We use them with a rope and pulley for taking asphalte from the ground, about 48 feet from the ground—there is a chain with a hook at the end of the rope—the chain is taken round the handle of the pail and then attached to the hook. I was at the top about 4 p.m. I hooked an empty pail on to the rope; I then threw it over and Avery began to lower; it had gone down about four feet, when agust of wind came and knocked the bucket right against the puddick, and the bucket was unhooked. I looked round, and saw the bucket separate from the rope and falling. No buckets had fallen before. I have asphalted the tops of other schools, and I never saw an accident before. The hook is supported by a spring, a single pulley only, one bucket going up and down at a time. My duty was to unhook the full pail and attach an empty one in its place."
NOT GUILTY . The Jury stated that stronger precautions ought to be taken in future to prevent accidents.

972.
HENEY WHITE (48)
, Feloniously carnally abusing
Gertrude Ellen Tribe, aged 13, and
Louisa Alice Wood, aged 12.
MESSRS. POLAND and HORACE AVORY Prosecuted; MESSRS. MONTAGU

GUILTY .—
Four Years' Hard Labour (Two Years' for each assault ).

973.
JOHN FRASER
, Rape on
Emily Marmon.
MESSRS. POLAND and MONTAGU WILLIAMS Prosecuted; MESSRS. GEOGHEGAN and CLUER Defended.

p.hi:
of the attempt.—
Two Years' Hard Labour.

div1.p:
974.
JOHN MEAD
, Robbery, with violence on
William Woods, and stealing a purse and 16s., his goods and money.

WILLIAM WOODS . I live at Pentonville Chambers, Pentonville Road, and am a coach painter—about half-past 12 on Sunday morning, 31st August, I was in the New Cut, when the prisoner, whom I see nightly in my sleep, caught me by my coat collar with one hand, and by the throat with the other, and ran me up against the shutters—there were three men with him, besides the one that carried my carpet bag—when against the shutters they pinned my arms and held my arms; I tried to get rid of the choking, I could hardly breathe—the prisoner rifled my pockets and turned them inside out, and he kept his grip on me till I fell down—they took my purse, 16s. or more, and some tobacco, and then they left me and ran away—I was taken to a lodging near by—a policeman came to me after that—next morning I identified the prisoner from several other persons—the prisoner used the violence to my throat, I suffered a great deal of pain—I was not able to speak for some hours afterwards—I have been spitting blood ever since, and am still suffering from the effects—I am 73 years old.
Cross-examined. I am sure you are the man—you nearly strangled me—I could not swear to the clothes you had on—I know your features.
By the COURT. I first saw him at a lamp-post with three other respectable looking men, but the man that had my carpet bag belonged to the school, and led me into the lion's den.

ALFRED WARD . From information I received, early on Sunday morning, 31st August, I made inquiries, and found the prisoner in a house in Langfranc Street, Waterloo Road, drinking with a number of others—I knew him before—I said "Johnny, I want you"—he said, "All right, sir, I know what you want me for; I suppose you will give me seven years for this"—I said, "I want you for that job in the City on Saturday night, being concerned with six other men in robbing an old gentleman"—I took him to the station, he was placed with six others of the same description, and when the prosecutor came in he immediately rushed at him—I had seen the prisoner about half-past one on the Sunday morning (this had occurred at half-past twelve, but I had then no knowledge of it), with three others, whom I know, at a coffee stall at the corner of Stamford Street, Waterloo Road—they were three well-dressed young fellows—they walked away and the prisoner remained behind—he knew me well—he said "Mr. Ward, are you not going to take Harry Nicholls?"—that was one of the three that walked away—I said "What for?"—he said "Haven't you heard?"—I said "No"—he said "I thought you knew all about it" (the coffee stall was about five minutes' walk from

the scene of the robbery)—I did not know what he was alluding to, I did not hear of the robbery till nine the following morning—at the station on the morning after he was identified and after the charge was made, he said "You have got me tight this time."
Cross-examined. I left you at the coffee-stall—I knew that the four men I saw there were thieves—the man I took to the station on the Sunday night was for another affair altogether.
WILLIAM WOODS (Re-examined by the COURT). I have not been well since this attack—I was perfectly sober.
The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate. "I am merely charged because I was seen at the coffee-stall."
GUILTY .

He then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony in March, 1881. Seven other convictions were proved against the prisoner.—Five 1882.
Years' Penal Servitude and
Twenty Strokes with the Cat.

975.
WILLIAM WALLIKEK (28)
, Stealing a watch and chain and 10l. in money of
Henry Clarkson, his master.

HENRY CLARKSON . I live at 142, Newport Street, Lambeth Walk, and am a contractor—on Bank Holiday, 4th August, about 11 a.m., I went out with my wife and children, leaving a gold watch and chain of the value of about 20l., in the drawers in my bedroom, and also about 10l. in gold and silver in the same drawer; there was also a diamond ring there, that was afterwards found on the floor—I got home about 10 or half-past 10 at night and found the door of the room burst open—we had left it barred up and then gone out of the front door and locked it, leaving nobody in the house—the bedroom-door had been prised open—when we came back we lit the lamp and saw the ring on the floor—the watch and chain were gone and about 10l. in gold and silver—this was on the ground floor—the prisoner has lodged with me two or three years, sleeping in a room on the ground floor, and was one of my carmen—on this morning he washed the trap and cleaned the harness before I went out—up to Bank Holiday night I think he had been in the habit of coming home regularly, on that night he did not come home—next night, Tuesday, I saw him with a woman at the Equestrian public-house at the side of the Surrey Theatre—he was three-parts drunk—he had not been to his work on the Tuesday—Constable Jupe was with me—I asked the prisoner "What have you done with the watch and chain?"—he made no answer, but stood there—I asked him about the money and told him what I had lost, and said "If you don't tell me where it is I shall lock you up"—he said nothing for a minute or two, but turned all manner of colours—I told him I had lost my misuses gold watch and chain that I gave 21l. for and about 10l. of my little children's gold and silver—I said nothing about the ring—he stood there for five minutes and made no answer, and then he said he did not know nothing about it and what he knew he was going to keep to himself—I gave him into custody—the prisoner knew all the ways of the house, as he had lived there—he had no business whatever in the bedroom or parlour.

JAMES HARMER . I am a carman in Mr. Clarkson's employment, and was so last Bank Holiday—I had just come back from my dinner and sat down in the yard when I saw the prisoner coming out from the door of the missus's bedroom into the yard—I did not see whether he had got anything—I was talking to another chap, Nickerboo, who works for Mr.

Clarkson—the prisoner could hear us; he said nothing to us—I asked him whether he was going to treat us, and we all went to the public-house and had something to drink, for which the prisoner paid—he changed half-a-crown for the first quart and a two-shilling piece for the second—he said nothing about the missus or how he had got the money—he asked me the time, and I told him, and he said he had to be at Camberwell at 1 o'clock—this visit to the Windmill was in working-hours, we were looking after the horses on the Bank Holiday—the prisoner had no business in the missus's bedroom—the wash-house which opens into the yard separates the missus's room from ours—you come into the wash-house, and then our room is on the left, and missus's room on the right—the door into the yard was open.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I can swear I saw you come out of that room, no one but you was there—the bedroom and parlour are separate rooms, leading into one another—there were three of us talking to
gether, McCarthy was the third—we were all treated—you did not speak as you came out—I said "Are you going to treat us out of that shilling the governor gave you for washing his trap?"—you said we could come over and have some of the beer—the George is nearer than the Windmill—you did not give Boo twopence because he said he had no money.
Re-examined. He changed no shilling at the Windmill.

LOUIS LOCKWOOD . I am one of the prosecutor's carmen, and live next door—on Tuesday, 5th of August, I went to the prisoner at the police-station and said "Walliker, tell me where the missus's watch and chain is?"—he turned round and said to me "I know nothing about it, they cannot get nothing out of me; let them try what they like"—I asked him the same question again and he made the same reply—I did not ask him why he had not been to work on Tuesday morning; the policeman took me away then.

HENRY JUPE (Detective Sergeant L). On the night of the 5th of August, at 10.30, I took the prisoner into custody at the Equestrian Tavern, Blackfriars Road—I said "You will be charged with stealing a watch and chain and 10l. in money from your master"—he made no reply, but said "I will go"—I searched him at once and found 3s. 6d. in silver on him, and 7 1/2 d. in bronze—I should say he had been drinking heavily—he was three-parts drunk; he was smoking a cigar and had a woman with him—on the way to the station he said "I know nothing about the b——things"—the bedroom of this house is partitioned off from the parlour—the door could be easily burst open, there is only a small bolt—my recollection is that it was a half-glass door; the glass was whole—the wash-house door was left open for the men to get water—he would go through there to burst open the door.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence stated that on this day he came out of his own bedroom, and seeing the men in the yard treated them at their request out of the shilling his master had given him, and that on leaving them he met a suc-ession of friends, who continued treating him until he was given into custody.

rs.hi: Judgment respited to give the prisoner an opportunity of giving some information as to the watch and chain.

div1.p:
976.
HENRY HOWARD (19) and
GEORGE SMITH (18)
, Stealing a pie and 1 lb. of cheese, the goods of
Robert George Scott.

p.hi: At the conclusion of the evidence the prisoners stated that they both intended to

div1.p: PLEAD GUILTY, upon which the Jury found a verdict of
GUILTY .

HOWARD then PLEADED GUILTY** to a conviction of felony at this Court in January, 1883—
Eighteen Months Hard Labour . SMITH*—
Nine Months Hard Labour.

977.
THOMAS JONES (19)
, Robbery with violence on
David Vine and stealing his watch and chain.
MR. SAUNDERS Prosecuted; MR. RAVEN Defended.

DAVID VINE . I am a blacksmith, living at Kennington Cross—on the 23rd of August, about a quarter or 20 minutes to 11, I was in the Westminster Bridge Road, when the prisoner and another man came up to me—the prisoner came right up to my face and put his hand up and threw me over—I fancy I was kicked up, because I had a great lump on my leg—the prisoner broke my chain and took my watch; this is the other part of my chain—when I got up the prisoner was running down the street—I don't know where the other went to—I was lame before this with rheumatics—my watch was worth 5l.—I have no doubt the prisoner is the man who took it.

Cross-examined. There was another man there; I did not recognise him as it was done so suddenly—I have not seen the prisoner before to my Knowledge—this was at the corner of Charles Street, on the public pavement—there was a lamp at the corner, and there I saw the two men standing as I crossed the street—I believe it was the other man that tripped me up—I shouldn't say the man who assaulted me had any whiskers—I am not very short-sighted; I can see better with glasses—I had my glasses on at the time—I did not notice that he was wearing a pin—I am positive he had a billycock hat on, I believe a black one—I believe the other had a black hat on, I could not swear to it—both of them had dark trousers on—I know nothing of the prisoner's character or that he holds a driver's licence.

By the COURT. Neither of them spoke—there were a lot of people looking on, no one interfered—for a week afterwards I suffered a great deal of pain; I had a lump as big as an egg under my knee, and my leg was grazed and my hands cut.

LOUISA STREET . I am the wife of Frederick Thomas Street, a colour
grinder, of 30, Westminster Bridge Road—about a quarter to 11 o'clock on 23rd August I heard cries of "Stop thief," and saw the prisouer running away in Charles Street—I am positive he is the man—I picked him out from about nine others at the police-station.

Cross-examined. I identified another man first, but after I went closer, and am quite sure now that this is the man—I was coming up Charles Street, which leads into Westminster Bridge Road—I saw only one man—no one was with me—I saw Mrs. Calloway there—I did not know her previously—the baker's wife was there too—I know she is the baker's wife because she came out of the shop, and I have seen her in the shop before—I don't know the baker's name—she is not here—I don't know whether Mr. Cadie, a shoemaker, lives in Charles Street, nor whether Mr. Calloway does—I said the prisoner had a slight moustache, not whiskers.
Re-examined. Mrs. Calloway came to the baker's corner that night that is why I recollect her so well.

MARY ANN CALLOWAY . I am the wife of William Calloway, a ladies' shoemaker, of 15, Charles Street—on the night of 23rd August I was standing; outside my door with my landlady—I heard a gentleman cry out, and then saw the prisoner trotting down Charles Street—I ran to the corner of the street by the baker's—the prisoner halted as he got to the corner, and then began to run very fast down Webber Row—I am quite sure the prisoner is he—he had a pin in his scarf then, and on the last remand I told him he had taken it out—I heard him tell Mr. Bridge he had the pin taken out of his scarf at the House of Detention—he had no whiskers; I could see marks of hair down his face, but since being in prison he has more of it—I went to the police-cell to identify him, but if was not light enough—when he came outside into the courtyard I told him he had taken the pin out of his scarf.

Cross-examined. Margaret Dougherty is my landlady—we were at the door—she says the prisoner is not the man, I say he is—it was between 9 and 10 o'clock—I had no means of knowing the proper time; it might have been a quarter to 11—he came from the top of Charles Street—I never said he came down Webber Street, that is a mistake—he came past my door and turned into Webber Row—our street is very dark—I was outside the door—I saw he had a pin in his scarf when I got to the baker's shop, which is well lighted—his whiskers have grown since I saw him; they were very slight then—he was placed with 11 man in such a dark cell that I could not see, and I did not identify him—when I came back on the Tuesday of the remand I talked to Mrs. Dougherty about it, and she said "Mrs. Calloway, it is not the man"—she was standing in the doorway with me.
Re-examined. She did not go to the corner where the lamp was.

FREDERICK GRAY (Detective L). On Saturday night, 23rd August, I was in the Westminster Bridge Road, about 10 or a quarter to 10 o'clock—I saw the prisoner in the Oxford public-house with another man, who is still wanted for being concerned with him in this case—that is about 30 yards from where this occurred.

Cross-examined. There was no other acquaintance of mine there—there were three remands for Calloway's attendance—I gave evidence on the second or third, the third I think—I was in Court on the two previous occasions.

ALFRED WARD (Sergeant L). On the morning of 26th August I appre
hended the prison or in the Westminster Bridge Road, and told him he would be charged with being concerned with another not in custody in stealing a watch—he said "All right, I think you have made a mistake this time"—when the charge was read over to him he said "I suppose I must put up with the law."

Cross-examined. If it is on the deposition that I said he said, "I will put up with the law,"I made a mistake—at the police-court his words were,"I must put up with the law"—I did not take a note of what he said—I have made inquiries about his character—I endeavoured to see Mr. Deards, a builder, of Westminster Bridge Road; I called, he was at the seaside—I saw Mr. Warne, a cabinet-maker, in the presence of the prisoner's father—he told me the prisoner was apprenticed to him, and two years ago he was obliged to cancel his indentures; I swear that—the prisoner had a police conductor's licence, it has never been used;
they are only given to people of good character, and is generally obtained on the result of inquiries—I cannot say whether it is correct or not.

Re-examined. Mr. Warne said he had been obliged to cancel the prisoner's indentures two years ago and to discharge him, and he said to the prisoner's father, "You know, Mr. Temple, he has been keeping very indifferent company lately, I have seen him with" so-and-so, mentioning different names—the father said he would wash his hands of him.

MARGARET DOUGHERTY . I am single, and the landlady's daughter—I was standing with Mrs. Calloway at the door on this night, and saw a man come down the street running—I do not see that man here; the prisoner is not the man I am satisfied—he was by himself—he had a dark moustache and no whiskers—I have known the prisoner for three years by standing outside my door, but I have never spoken to him—I know nothing about the prisoner's character.
By the COURT. He was in the volunteers, and they used to assemble outside my window.

Cross-examined. Charles Street is badly lighted; there is one lamp, and one lamp over the baker's door—the lamp was next door to where I was standing, about a dozen yards off—I went to the corner with Mrs. Calloway; we all followed to the corner after the man ran away—he had got into the Waterloo Road by the time we got to the corner, and we did not see him, he had gone.

MARGARET TEMPLE .
