I am the prisoner's mother—the prisoner lived with us until quite recently—the last time he slept in our house was the night before Bank Holiday—he had a conductor's licence—his father in at work and not able to come here—I never heard his father say he would wash his hands of him—he shed bitter tears when we heard of it—I believe he was always an honest lad—after the statement of the sergeant that he was dismissed from his apprenticeship I saw Mr. Warne's manager, and Mr. Warne wrote this memorandum—he was in Mr. Deard's employ, and he entrusted him with 60l. or 70l.—he is out of town.

p.hi: The Jury here intimated that they had made up their minds, and returned a verdict of

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

978.
WALTER WILKINSON (34)
PLEADED GUILTY to a burglary in the dwelling-house of
James William Chisholm, and stealing 22l.—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

979.
HENEY O'SHEA (18)
to robbery with violence on
Paul Gerrard, and stealing his watch-chain; also to a conviction of felony in December, 1883.—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.] And

980.
FREDEEICK STANLEY (46)
to breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Caroline Dust, with intent to steal; also** to a con
viction of felony in September, 1871.—
Eight Years' Penal Servitude.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

981.
ELLEN SMITH (26)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

EMMA HILL . I am barmaid at the Winchester Arms, Southwark Street—on 21st August, about 2 o'clock, the prisoner came in and asked for a glass of ale, tendering a half-crown, which I tried in the tester and broke—I handed it to Mr. Kemp, the landlord—he told me to give it back to
the prisoner—I gave it to her, and asked her if she knew it was a bad one—she said she did not, and told me she had taken it at the pledge shop in Union Street; she told Mr. Kemp the same.

GEORGE KEMP . On 21st August, at 2 o'clock, the prisoner came in—I saw Emma Hill take some coin and put it in the tester; I stood by her and saw it break—I said to the barmaid "Go and ask her where she got it from"—she said "I got it from a pawnshop"—I said "It is a lie, show me your ticket"—she said "I won't"—I said "I shall send for a con
stable and give you in charge"—she said "You can do so, and then I won't show you the ticket"—I sent for a constable and gave her in charge—she said the pawnshop was in Union Street; that has been shut up for years.

ABBAHAM SURREY (Policeman M 300). I was called to the Winchester Arms, and Mr. Kemp gave the prisoner into custody, saying the prisoner had come in for a glass of ale "Tendering me this half-crown," handing me a half-crown—I said to her "How did you come by it?"—she said "I got it at a pawnshop where I pawned my shawl"—I asked her for the ticket—she said "I shan't show it to you, now you know, do as you like"—she said the landlady had pawned the shawl in Union Street, Borough, and she had got the ticket—at the station in answer to the charge she said "The shawl was pawned in Union Street by the land
lady, and she has got the ticket"—she gave her address at 5l., Little Surrey Street—there is no pawnshop in Union Street, it has been done away with for two and a half years—before the Magistrate she said she had got the half-crown by selling a bunch of flowers to a gentleman, and afterwards told the old story that the landlady had pawned the shawl.
ELIZABETH REEVES . I live at 51, Little Surrey Street, Blackfriars Road—the prisoner lodged with me on 21st August—I have never pawned a shawl for her.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . This is a bad half-crown.

p.hi: The prisoner in her defence stated that she gave the shawl to a woman to pawn, and that the woman gave her the half-crown and a penny, but that the woman could not now be found, as she had gone to the hop country.

div1.p: GUILTY .

p.hi:
She then PLEADED GUILTY** to a conviction of felony for having a galvanic battery for the manufacture of counterfeit coin in her possession at this Court in January, 1881, in the name of Ellen Raynor.—
Five Years' Penal Servitude.

div1.p:
982.
THOMAS CLIFFORD (29)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

GEORGE FRYER . I am barman at the Plasterers' Arms public-house, Seymour Street, Euston Square—on 16th May I was barman at the Win
chester public-house, Southwark Bridge Road—on that day, at 11 p.m., the prisoner came in with another man and called for a pot of ale, tendering a two shilling piece in payment—I gave him 1s. 8d. change, and put the florin on a shelf by itself; there was no other florin there—my missis afterwards took it up and showed it to me; I found it was bad and broke it in two—the prisoners were in the house at the time—I cannot say if they saw it broken—I went to look for a constable—the prisoner went outside two or three minutes afterwards—they saw the

missis speaking and showing it to me—I stopped the prisoner as he was running away—a constable came up and I gave him into custody—he said he received the florin in his wages—I gave it to the constable—the prisoner was charged and discharged after a remand—as soon as he saw me going for a constable the prisoner came out of the door and began to run directly.

GEORGE LOMAS (Policeman M 37). On 16th May I was on duty in Suffolk Street, Southwark Bridge Road, and saw the last witness holding the prisoner—I went up—Fryer said "I give this man into custody for passing a bad florin in the Winchester public-house, 201, Southwark Bridge Road"—he handed me a florin broken into these two pieces—the prisoner said "I have been working at St. Olave's Wharf, Tooley Street, to-day; I got the money there"—I searched him at the station and found 1s. 6d. in silver and eight coppers on him—he gave the name of Patrick Brennan—he was charged at Southwark Police-court and discharged.

ELIZABETH RAINER . I am single and keep a chandler's shop at 115, Broad Wall, Southwark—at half-past 9 on the evening of 21st July, the prisoner came in and asked for a pennyworth of bread and a pennyworth of cheese, offering me a shilling—I saw by its look it was bad—this (produced) appears like it—I bent it in the tried—I said "Well, young man, this is No. 3 to-day, it is quite time this was stopped"—he said nothing, but pretended to be intoxicated by leaning against the place; he could not stand up—he spoke properly when he came in and asked for the bread and cheese—he said he had taken it where he was working—he gave the name of some docks, I cannot say what—I sent for a con
stable and gave him in charge—I had had other bad shillings tendered earlier on the same day, one at half-past 5 and one at eight, and I saw the prisoner outside the door when the one at 5.30 was offered me; and the man that offered it and the prisoner went away together, and seemed to be friends—I gave both the bad shillings to the constable.

Cross-examined. You did not appear to be under the influence of drink—I took the money up, turned my back to you, and came and said it was bad, and you said "I was not aware of it," and that you received it in your work.

HENRY ROUSE (Policeman L 63). I was called to 115, Broad Walk—Elizabeth Rainer and the prisoner were in the shop—Miss Rainer pro
duced this shilling and said she had had three bad shillings tendered that day—the first I do not know who broke—the second she gave to me and said "This was brought to me by a man about an hour ago"—and about the third she said "This man has given me this shilling; I tested it and found it was bad, and then sent for a constable"—the prisoner said "I did not know it was bad, I received it in wages last Saturday at St. Olave's Wharf, Bermondsey—I searched him in the shop and found a penny and an empty purse—I took him to the station—he was charged and said he had it at St. Olave's Wharf—he gave his address at St. Olave's Chambers, Tabard Street, a common lodging house.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . These two shillings and this florin are all bad—the shillings belong to the same mould.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence stated that he was a dock labourer, and received the shilling in pay the night before, and had no idea that it was bad.

div1.p:
GUILTY **.—
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour.

983.
WILLIAM WARD (18)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

FRANCES COWEN . I am shop woman to Mr. John Bennett, a baker, of 172 Tooley Street—at a quarter to nine on 29th July the prisoner came in and asked for a penny cake and tendered this half-crown in payment—I gave him 2s. 5d. change—I put the halt-crown in the till where there was one other which I am quite sure was good—it had been given me during the day—I put this in the tester, it broke—the week after I was fetched to Kennington Road Police-station and I picked out the prisoner from several others as the man that tendered the half-crown.
Cross-examined. I had not seen you before that night—I knew you again by your height.

GEORGE POCOCK . I am landlord of the Windsor Castle, West Street, Southwark—about 9.30 on 29th July my barmaid made a communication to me—I went to the bar and saw the prisoner there—I said "This is a bad half-crown," showing him the one—he said he got it from his master where he worked, and he produced a brass ticket with "E. D. Bennett & Co., Swan Lane Iron works, 58 morning," on it—he asked for the halt-crown back—I refused to give it—I asked him for the money for the ale which he had drunk—he walked outside the house—I followed and gave him into custody by the Spa Tavern, which is just by Spa Road, at the corner of which is the wall of some chocolate works, but some houses separate Spa Road from the wall—it was a dark night.
Cross-examined. You said you were very sorry, you did not know it was bad, and pulled out a ticket which I understood you got from your master.
Re-examined. I walked by his side the whole way from my house—I did not observe anything.

MARIAN SPENCER . "I am barmaid at the Windsor Castle—on 29th July the prisoner came and asked for a pint of ale, tendering a half-crown in payment—I cannot say if this is the one—I rang it on the counter, thought it was bad, and took it to Mr. Pocock and made a communication to him.
Cross-examined. I put it in the till, gave it to another lady, and she took it away and gave it to the governor—I did not hear you say you were very sorry.

GEORGE GRIFFEN (Policeman M 36). I was called to the Windsor Castle and Mr. Pocock gave the prisoner into my custody for attempting to pass a bad half-crown—he said "I am the one"—I said "You will have to go to the station with me"—I took him to the station—he admitted passing it but did not know it was bad—he made two statements—one that it was given to him at the Borough Market and the other that he got it from his employer—he said he got it for pulling a barrow from Borough Market to some green for a man who gave him a half-crown and left him—on 2nd August I received these five half-crowns from Wm. Skinner—he did not keep the paper in which they were wrapped.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You said you did not get it at your work but for pulling a barrow from Borough Market to Camberwell Green—but you made another statement as well, that you got it from your employer—they were two distinct statements.
WILLIAM SKINNER . I am a foreman of the chocolate works, 89, Spa Road—on 30th July at 7 o'clock a.m. I found five half-crowns wrapped

up in a strip of paper one and a half inches wide and 15 inches long lying about four or five feet from the wall. which is about 40 yards from the Spa Tavern, that is one side of the road and the chocolate works on the other—walking from West Street you would leave our works to the right—there were marks of coin on the paper—the coins were given to Griffen on the Saturday following.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . These two half-crowns that were uttered and these five found under the wall are all bad—the two uttered and three of the five are all from the same mould.

JOSEPH COLLINS . I am a labourer, living at 11, Elpherton Street, Old Kent Road—I left you at half-past 8 p.m. on the night of 29th July—I was working for Mowlem and Burt at the back of St. George's Barracks—the job was stopped and I was out of work for a week, and I went down to your house on 22nd July about half-past 4 o'clock and asked you to come for a walk to St. George's Barracks to see if they had started—we went all rouud the park and round and back by the Strand—coming back you asked me to lend you a shilling, you said your hand was better and you were going to start work on Monday and would give it back to me on Saturday—I did so, and we went into a public-house at the corner of the Westminster Bridge Road—then we came out and I asked you to go to Mr. King's to get a trowel, and you left me then at about half-past 8 o'clock—you said you had been up to Walworth; you said you had earned something and had something to pay away, and you showed me a half-crown.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence stated that on this day he pulled a barrow to Camberwell Green and that the gentleman he did it for gave him a half-crown, that he then had dinner when Collins came in, and that they went for a walk till half-past 8 o'clock, and that he offered the half-crown without knowing it was bad.

div1.p:
GUILTY †—
Six Months' Hard Labour.

984.
THOMAS GROVES (22)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin and having another in his possession.

SARAH GOODALL . I am Thomas Henry Goodall's wife—we keep a general shop at 289, St. James's Road, Bermondsey—at 11 o'clock on 8th August the prisoner and another man came in—the other man asked for two bottles of ginger-beer and laid down this half-crown—I looked at it and said "This is a bad one"—I bent it—he said "Don't break it, I may get another in place of it, I took three yesterday for my week's wages, all the money I have in my possession is a penny"—I said "Never mind, that will do"—I gave him the half-crown back—he put it in his pocket and said to his friend "Come along," mentioning some name, and they both went out and up St. James's Road—I spoke to a neighbour about a quarter of an hour afterwards—the prisoner was brought back to my shop—I identified the half-crown at the station.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You drank all the ginger-beer—when you came out of the shop with the detective you did not say "Did I give you this half-crown?"—I took a good half-crown out of my till and said "You can feel the difference between the two"—he felt them, and said "I think this," which was the one he had tendered, "is a bad half-crown."

ELIJAH TALBOT (Policeman M 263). On the morning of the 8th of August, at 11 o'clock, I was on duty at St. James's Road—the prisoner and another man passed me walking quickly—I followed the prisoner; he crossed the road and ran when he saw Gaertner, another constable, speak to me—I followed him to the corner of the Old Kent Road, and then being out of breath Gaertner followed—the prisoner was brought back—as we ran he passed 324, St. James's Road.

JOHN GAERTNER (Detective M). Talbot made a communication to me—I followed the prisoner who was running and arrested him in Peckham Park Road—I said "I am a police officer, what were you running for just now in St. James's Road?"—he replied "I have not been in the St. James's Road, neither have I been running"—I took him to Mrs. Goodhall's shop; she identified him as having been with another man who had attempted to pass a bad half-crown—I saw the prisoner pass 324—I produce seven counterfeit half-crowns given me by Mayhew; I showed them to Mrs. Goodhall, she picked out this one—it has signs of having been bent—it was then marked.

Cross-examined. I searched you at the station, there was nothing found on you—you told me that you did not know the other man, that he asked you to go and have a bottle of ginger-beer with him, haying met him close to the shop.

HENRY OLIVER . I am a clicker, and live at 324, St. James's Road—I have a little garden in front of my house—about half-past 11 on the 8th of August I saw a packet under the portico; I picked it up, it con
tained these three half-crowns wrapped up—on the grass I saw another packet, containing four half-crowns, also wrapped up in paper—I gave them to Mayhew.

FREDERICK MAYHEW (Policeman M 261). Oliver made a communica
tion to me, and handed me these seven half-crowns, which I took to the station and gave to Gaertner; four in one packet and three in another.

WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . These seven half-crowns are all bad—the one that has been tested is not from the same mould as any of the others—there are no marks of the coins on the paper, which is like the professional paper used.
The Prisoners Statement before the Magistrate. "It was not me, sir, it was the man that asked me to have the ginger-beer. I don't know who he was."

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence stated that he met the other man, who offered to treat him to some ginger-beer, and that he went into the shop with him, but that not liking the man's company after the affair about the half-crown, he started running at soon as he got outside the shop in order to get away from him.

div1.p: SARAH GOODHALL (Re-examined by the Court). The other man tendered the half-crown, and asked for the bottle of ginger-beer.

GUILTY *†—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

985.
ROBERT CUNNINGHAM DOYLE (53) and
MARGARET HENDERSON (40)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.
MR. GOODRICH Prosecuted; MR. MONTAGU WILLIAMS Defended.

NESTORE ROSALI . I keep a confectioner's shop, at 117, Westminster Bridge Road—at 11 a.m. on 1st September I was serving with my wife; the female prisoner came in and asked for a quarter of a pound of ham; I was about to serve her, and then she said only two ounces—that came

to 2d.—she tendered a half-crown, which my wife took and gave to me—I bent it in my teeth and made three teeth marks on the bottom of the date—2s. 4d. change was given her—she left the house—I followed her directly, stopped her, and asked her to be kind enough to give me another half-crown, because that was not good—she said she was quite certain that was good, and she came back to the shop, left the ham and change, and went away, saying she would bring the man who gave the change to her in three minute's time—in about three-quarters of an hour she was brought back by Rose—this is the coin I bent, with the marks of my teeth on it—she said she was certain the half-crown was good, and that it came from my place.
Cross-examined. My wife passed the half-crown to me and she gave the change—I tried it in my teeth and bent it—the prisoner was indoors when my wife gave it me.

MARIAN ROSATI . I am the last witness's wife—about 11 o'clock on 1st September the female prisoner came in, asked for some ham, and ten
dered a half-crown to me—I gave her change, putting the half-crown on the marbleslab at the back—I afterwards gave it to my husband—I gave the prisoner a two-shilling piece change and four coppers—she said the florin was a bad one—I took it back and gave her another—her half-crown was on the marble slab from the time I put it there to the time I gave it to my husband.
Cross-examined. I put the money on the slab—there were two florins and two sixpences there—I got my change from the back—she saw me put the half-crown at the back—there was no other half-crown there.

GERALD GRIFFIN . I am a barman at the Hercules, in Kennington Road—about half-past 10 o'clock I was serving; the male prisoner came in and asked for a half-quartern of fivepenny rum in a bottle—it came to 2 1/2 d.—he tendered a half-crown—I noticed it was already dented and rather bad, and I broke it in the tester—he said he had got it from a respectable house of business—my governor sent for a constable; he was given in charge—about half an hour afterwards I noticed the female prisoner in the other bar—I did not serve her—I gave the half-crown to the constable.

Cross-examined. The male prisoner insisted the half-crown was a good one, he asked the constable to take it to a jeweller's shop and have it tested—I believe it was sent from the police-station to a jeweller's, and the first jeweller said it was a good one—it was afterwards sent to two others.

HENRY BENNETT (Policeman L 218). On 1st September I was called to the Hercules, and the male prisoner was given into my custody—I received these pieces from the last witness—the prisoner denied it was bad, and wanted to claim it back again—he is brother-in-law to the female prisoner.

WILLIAM ROSE (Detective Sergeant L). On 1st September I was on duty at the Kennington Road Station when the male prisoner was brought in and charged with having attempted to pass a bad half-crown to Gerald Griffin—he was detained for me to make inquiries—he asked me to go to the Alma Coffee-house, ask for Miss Henderson, not for his wife, and she would tell me that she had received the half-crown from a ham and beef shop in the Westminster Bridge Road—I went to the Alma Coffee-house, saw the female prisoner, and she told me she went there for two ounces

of ham, handed a half-crown, and received a bad two-shilling piece and 4d. change—I said she had better go to the shop with me; she did so—the proprietor, Nestore Rosati, said he recollected the female being in the shop during the morning, that she had been in for two ounces of ham, for which she put down a half-crown, which was afterwards detected to be bad, and that she ran out of the shop after that—on that I took her into custody, telling her it was a bad half-crown—the said, "No, it was a bad two-shilling piece you gave me"—she was afterwards taken to the station and charged.
SARAH ANN ROWLES . I keep a coffee-house at 5, Mount Street, Lambeth—on 30th August the two prisoners came to my house and slept there for two nights.
Cross-examined. The prisoner, his wife, and this woman.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . These are four pieces of a bad half-crown.
Doyle's Statement before the Magistrate. "I believed it was a good half-crown. I got it at a respectable shop, and gave it to my sister.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1884.
